Body: Description: We got an external mail that one of our public URL is exposing some sensitive encryption keys and configuration data. I need to understand the criticality and severity of this and where it is hosted. Note: Before proceeding with any fixes or activity for the given URL, let's have a discussion first. I will be scheduling a call with you for better clarification of this, in the meantime please go through the details. URL: https://dlp.gameskraft.com/easylock/generatedData/metadata.txt Below is the procedure and impact that is shared by an external person ( bug bounty hunter ). Steps to Reproduce: Navigate to https://dlp.gameskraft.com/easylock/generatedData/metadata.txt Observe the displayed data which includes encryption keys (ivMp, saltMp, mpPub, encMpPrivByMp), unique identifiers (elId), and various configuration settings (pingInterval, passwordRules). Expected Result: Sensitive data, especially related to encryption and system configurations, should not be accessible via a public URL. Access should be restricted to authorized personnel through secured means. Actual Result: Encryption keys and configuration data are openly accessible through a public URL without any form of authentication or access control. Impact: This exposure can lead to potential security breaches, unauthorized data access, and could be exploited by malicious entities to compromise the systemâ€™s security, decrypt sensitive data, or conduct targeted attacks.
